source.query: one arm dead hang muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The One-Arm Dead Hang is an advanced isometric exercise primarily targeting forearm flexors, grip strength, shoulder stabilizers (like rotator cuff), lats, and core to prevent twisting, with significant activation in traps and biceps for stability. The movement pattern involves an isometric hold where your entire body weight is supported by one arm, demanding immense unilateral strength, improving shoulder health, and correcting imbalances, making it a potent preparation for advanced calisthenics like one-arm pull-ups. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Forearms: Deep forearm muscles (flexors) work intensely to maintain the grip. 
• Grip: Finger flexors and intrinsic hand muscles are heavily challenged. 
• Shoulders: Rotator cuff, deltoids, and scapular stabilizers (traps, rhomboids) build stability and strength in a deep range of motion. 
• Back: Latissimus dorsi (lats) and trapezius (traps) engage to keep the shoulder girdle stable and stretched. 
• Core: Abdominals and obliques work isometrically to prevent your body from swinging or rotating. 
• Biceps: Engage to assist in stabilizing the elbow and shoulder. [1, 3, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Grip: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand, using a pronated (overhand) or supinated (underhand) grip. 
2. Support: Hang with your body suspended, keeping your arm extended or slightly bent. 
3. Stability (Isometric): Your core and upper back muscles contract to keep your torso still and prevent swaying. 
4. Duration: Hold for a set time, focusing on deep breathing and maintaining tension. 
5. Unilateral Challenge: The key is that one arm supports your total body weight, forcing extreme unilateral strength development. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]
